div.p: As the spread of Coronavirus (COVID-19) continues to evolve, we, as a school division, will continually sharethe details of our plans during this public health crisis.

hr.p: We have finished up the first week of new instruction, and the first full month of online instruction. It is amazing to reflect on how far we have come! Thank you again for all of your support during this time. Below you will find our latest updates on the many projects we are continuing to work on during the closure to keep FCCPS moving forward.

The construction at GMHS remains on schedule and on budget. We are excited to see the exteriors of the new building going up and the interior beginning to take shape. On that note, I wanted to engage all of you and have a little fun helping us with The GMHS Time Capsule.

Before schools closed, George Mason High Schools Yearbook Team started the process of collecting items to place in a new George Mason High School time capsule. Students aimed to collect an array of content - photographs, memos, athletic uniforms, banners, books, letters, report cards, lunch menus, tech devices, and more - that would be interesting for people to discover decades from now.

Lets not let the COVID-19 pandemic stop the momentum! Were encouraging all George Mason High School community members: students (former, current, and future), parents, staff, associated groups, coaches, etc. to look around your homes for items that could be placed in the time capsule. Were also encouraging our GMHS Seniors to write letters to the future as a way to share memories of your high school experience.
Once youve found items/written letters, etc...please:

ol.li: Photograph what youd like to submit.
Attach a photograph of your item/document to an email addressed tonewgmhs@gmail.com
In the subject field type: Time Capsule Submission.

In the body of the email, identify who you are: Full name, association to GMHS and phone number. Also, describe what youre submitting with a title, date, and briefdescription. Dont forget to attach the photo of what youre submitting and/ordocument to the email.
Submissions will be accepted until Memorial Day (May 25, 2020).

hr.p: The GMHS Yearbook Team Members and FCCPS will work together to review all submissions based on guidelines, relevance, and the time capsule dimensions, which are approximately 1 W x 7 L (8 total area). Everyone who submitted Time Capsule Submission emails will be contacted and made aware of the Yearbook Team and FCCPS final decisions. When school is reopened, a process will be shared for collecting selected items. While some items may not be selected for final placement, were confident that many will. Also, anyone who proposes items will be acknowledged in a time capsule memo even if their item isnt selected for final placement.
School Budget Update and My Letter to Staff Regarding Budget

This week I had to deliver some tough news to our faculty and staff. Due to COVID-19, and the subsequent projected losses in City and State revenue, the budget I proposed and the School Board advertised is not the budget we will be able to deliver for next year.

I am attaching the letter to Faculty and Staff here in case you want to read what I said to team FCCPS: https://bit.ly/3aim3Ku . At this time we are fortunate that it doesnt look like we will need to reduce staff or cut jobs. However, all additional funding is eliminated and the impacts include no compensation increases for teachers and staff next year and no additional instructional positions.

Some of you may ask...how can we help...and there are a number of ways... Because FCCPS is so reliant on local funds to support our schools, and the majority of the projected lost revenue is in sales tax and meals tax, we encourage you to shop and eat locally. Even during this pandemic, there are ways to eat via take-away and delivery from restaurants in The Little City and shop online for groceries and other goods to pick up to stay safe. Please consider staying in the City of Falls Church when you spend your money so you can support our schools.

FCCPS continues to provide weekly meal support each Friday. Any family in need can order 7-days worth of breakfasts and lunches for each child in their family. Please visit our FCCPS Nutritional/Support Webpage for information on how to sign up for this wonderful resource. All my best, and we miss you!
Peter

Dear FCCPS Families,

Welcome back to school! I hope you all had a great spring break, albeit different, and you and your students feel ready for the challenge of new material. This week marks a turning point for us in FCCPS insofar as we will begin to introduce new content to our students PK-12. As mentioned previously, we would much prefer to be face-to-face, but here we are...I believe what our amazing teachers have planned for your students will be excellent, given the circumstances. The guidance I gave to our teachers as we begin the spring is that there is no expectation that what happens in the next several weeks will be perfect. We are engaged in an imperfect educational solution, and the speed of implementation has been nothing short of breakneck. Let's be reasonable, flexible, and let graciousness be our guide. Lets not let perfection get in the way of progress. I am confident that our community can rally around this and help us all be successful.
To try and restore as much normalcy as we can, the Morning Announcements resumed today, and I hope you had a chance to see them. We will keep these up, like usual, for the remainder of the year.

Additionally, in an effort to resume normal operations, please be on the lookout for the Teacher of the Year, Professional Specialist of the Year, and Support Employee of the Year announcements this week. We are excited to announce them via video starting Wednesday (likely). I know you will all be proud of the selections and will join me in celebrating our designees this year.

I was recently sent an article that outlines lessons learned from Hong Kong International School who went through what we are going through several months ago https://www.learningpersonalized.com/we-did-not-sign-up-for-this-9-lessons-learned-from-a-hong-kong-principal-on-facing-a-crisis/ . The article reminds us that there is the Triage phase, a Transition phase, and a Post-Epidemic phase. I would submit we are moving out of the Triage phase and are entering into the Transition phase. The good news is that due to the great planning of our school team we anticipated the triage phase, which helped us mobilize quickly and are now on our way to the post-pandemic phase - albeit aways awayit is something we can collectively look forward to.

Communications from me will shift slightly now that Morning Announcements have resumed. I will continue to communicate but only once a week on Fridays. I will continue to use Twitter also to send messages out (including my Wednesday videos from somewhere in FCCPS), so please follow me @peternoonan. Our FCCPS COVID-19 Page is full of resources to support students and their families as well, so please visit. Also, our schools will continue to do their weekly updates.

This past week I was on one of our long family walks we have become accustomed to during this time. We got deep into our conversation and realized what many of you are probably realizing as wellwe are grieving. We are grieving the loss of school, the loss of our friendships in the form we know them, the personal interactions with others in life, the ebb and flow of how the world works, etc I share this because it is important to reflect on and acknowledge this grief so that we can move through it. With the shift into new instruction, we head into more uncharted territory, and this, coupled with the losses we are already experiencing, can be daunting and stressful. However, our family remains heartened by the reminder that this is not a forever momentin fact, we are hoping to be on the other side of this within a matter of months. So, stay strong!

Lastly, I will share the Noonan/Letiecq/Dineen motto at our house as we move through our daily lives with school and work in an increasingly intertwined way (we had 5 Zoom calls going at the same time yesterday!). Do the best you can, let reasonability be your guide, and give each other gracious space. It is working for us, and I hope it works for you too.
All my best and we miss you!
Peter

Dear FCCPS Family,

We were reflecting as a leadership team today that March 13, 2020 seems like a year ago, but it was merely three weeks ago. In that time we have come a long way, made some decisions that we believe will work for the school division going forward, and garnered the support of the vast majority of the community moving forward. We are committed to ensuring that learning continues for our students, provide support for our families in need, and paying our employees...those feel like the right waypoints for success moving ahead.

We are proud of the efforts of all in our community and schools. Further, we are so appreciative of the gratitude you have shown for our teachers. This week I saw dozens of tulips delivered to the home of a teacher, a care package with survival items (chocolate, EmergenC, a book, etc) to another, and more. We know teachers and staff are important in the lives of your children and they are equally important in theirs. I speak for us all when I say thank you for your kindness and appreciation.

As we head into spring break we are going to take some downtime as a team to recoup and recover from the last three weeks. I hope you and your family will too as I am confident if my family constellation is any guide, the challenges of managing school, work, and life are intense.

I have asked our team to take some downtime this week to prepare for the final push of the year. If you send an email to us over the break, please be patient and know we will get back to you but may not right away.
Here are a few updates for you:

Grading and Reporting Plan

First, I want to thank everyone for their input on how best to handle grading and reporting in FCCPS going forward. Weve received a significant amount of email about this issue and, even as of yesterday, it was a topic in the GMHS Lasso. Every students circumstance is different and that was evident in the emails we received.
The critical questions we utilized to make this complicated and complex decision were:

ul.li: What solution honors the work of students and teachers up to March 12, 2020?
What solution recognizes meaningful learning of that content and skills?
What solution supports meaningful learning of content and skills prospectively and following Spring Break?
What solution will do no harm to students?
What solution is fair and equitable considering every student's circumstance is unique?

hr.p: Lastly, as the grading and reporting plan was conceived and considered we recognize that there is no one solution that will be satisfactory to everyone. However, with the aforementioned guideposts, we believe this is the best solution for the vast majority of students in FCCPS.

All PreK-12 students in FCCPS are expected to actively engage and fully participate in new learning which will begin on April 14, 2020. Content that is provided between April 14th and May 29th is considered new learning and is essential for academic success in the subsequent grade level. During this time teachers will provide self-directed learning opportunities, synchronous (live) and asynchronous (recorded) instruction based on the standards that have not yet been covered that are considered to be most critical to the curriculum (power standards). As we move into this important phase of new learning we want to recognize and support the progress that students made during the beginning of the 3rd quarter. Therefore, students will have an opportunity to turn in missing work that was assigned during the 3rd quarter (January 27th - March 12th). This 7-week learning window included face-to-face instruction and occurred prior to the launch of the continuity of online learning on March 19th. We believe that providing an opportunity for students to turn in missing work that was assigned during this window will lay a solid foundation of learning and allow many of our students to finish the year in a strong fashion.
Elementary Grading Plan

For the third quarter (Q3), Thomas Jefferson will issue Q3 marks/grades. Q3 grades at Thomas Jefferson will be based on student progress through March 12th. Teachers will assess progress and enter feedback and comments to finalize those Q3 grades.

Mount Daniel & Thomas Jefferson will issue a universal Pass or Fail (P/F) for the third trimester and fourth quarter (Q4) respectively. P/F is based on a student's mastery of learning, work completion, daily participation, and active engagement in online learning. From April 14th - June 4th, teachers will provide parents and students meaningful/guiding feedback and track student progress. P will be awarded to elementary level students.
Secondary Grading Plan

Quarter 3 Grade - Both Henderson and Mason will issue a 3rd quarter (Q3) grade based on the work completed between January 27th - March 12th. A students grade cannot go down as a result of any missing work that was not submitted during this window. However, students are expected to turn in missing work that was assigned during the 3rd quarter (January 27th - March 12th) prior to the launch of the continuity of learning which began on March 19th. We recognize that in some courses there were a minimal number of grades/assessments. Consequently, if a student wishes to improve upon the grades from prior assignments from January 27th - March 12th they will have that opportunity. To ensure the highest level of learning and mastery of prior content, the deadline for when students need to submit and/or resubmit missing Q3 work has been extended through the end of the year.

Students participating in our standards-based grading (SBG) courses have demonstrated mastery of several criterion to date. In January, your student received a S1 converted score which is located in PowerSchool. Your students current overall score in Schoology consists of all summative assessments though March 12th. The score from March 12th will be converted to a letter grade using our official FCCPS overall IB MYP conversion chart, and issued as a Q3 grade.

Students have the ability to retake summative assessments delivered from January 27th - March 12th to improve their Q3 grade. Teachers in SBG courses will continue to deliver instruction and provide feedback on assessed criterion as we embark on new learning and will issue a pass/fail (P/F) in Q4 to align with our secondary grading plan.
Secondary New Learning (April 14th - May 29th)

For the fourth quarter (Q4), Henderson & Mason will issue a universal P/F based on the student's level of mastery of learning, work completion, active participation, and engagement in online learning. Students semester two (S2) grade will be determined based on their quarter three (Q3) grade plus participation in online new learning in Q4. If a student is satisfied with their Q3 grade they still must engage in the new learning during Q4 in order to earn a pass P.

Failure to earn a P in Q4 will result in academic counseling and conferencing at the school level to identify curriculum and skill gaps that require closing via an individualized student learning plan in Summer/Fall of 2020.

FCCPS Nutritional Program Available for Families - Updated

In response to the extended closure due to the COVID-19 public crisis, FCCPS is proud to provide ongoing meal support to our students and their families. Each week ANY family in need, not just those who participate in the Free and Reduced Meals Program, can order (7) Breakfasts and (7) lunches for each child in their family.

The meals will be boxed and ready to pick up at their preferred location, either George Mason High School or Thomas Jefferson Elementary School. Families will need to order their meals by each Wednesday at 2:00 pm and they can be picked up each Friday morning between 9 am and 12 noon, observing safe social/physical distancing. The program began April 3rd and will run through the length of the school closure.

Families will submit orders each week by Wednesday at 2 pm for food distribution, two days later, on Friday. The Deadline is to allow our Food Service staff time to prepare the meals for each family for distribution. Instructions on how to order food each week, including a video that will walk you through step by step, are available at https://www.fccps.org/o/fccps/page/nutritional-food-support
FCCPS Nutrition Program has key differences as compared to other school divisions:

ol.li: Families can select seven (7) breakfasts and seven (7) lunches for every child in the family each week from the NutriSlice application. We are providing food to cover families for Saturday and Sunday as well...and even over Spring Break.

Our families need to make only one trip each week to receive food - seven days in one pickup. We are supporting our families efforts to stay home as much as possible to prevent the spread of COVID-19. Daily trips can also be difficult for families without transportation and younger children.
Families who may miss the Wednesday at 2 pm order deadline are not left without food. They can contact our Food Service Director, Richard Kane, via email at rkane@fccps.org.
Our meals consist of substantial items such as fresh produce, frozen proteins, and ingredients for meals that can be cooked rather than are simply Grab-n-Go.
And, we have two pick up locations (Thomas Jefferson Elementary and George Mason High School). This supports our families without transportation.

br.p: FCCPS has worked exceedingly hard to ensure our families are supported throughout this public health crisis. This is especially true in the area of Nutritional Support. We distributed over 130 boxes containing two-weeks of non-perishable food at the onset of our closure to ensure our Free and Reduced Meals Program (FRM) families were supported. Each family also, through the generosity of the Falls Church Education Foundation received a $50 grocery gift card per child to purchase additional food and items needed.

We will continue to provide weekly food through the end of the school year to ANY family, not just those who are in the FRM program - exceeding the standards set by state and federal requirements. And thanks to the ongoing support of the FCEF and our PTAs another round of gift cards to our families will be on its way.

Special Education and 504 Students Instructional Support:

As we begin to offer new learning on April 14th, please be reassured that our students with IEPs and 504 Plans will continue to be supported. While this new distance learning environment can never replicate what would be provided in the traditional school setting for our students with disabilities, know that our Regular Education Teachers, Special Education Teachers, 504 Case Managers, and Related Services staff will be there to help guide and assist our students. This support will include: personalized instructional assistance, 1:1 conferences, emails, telephonic help, synchronous (live) lessons, asynchronous (recorded) lessons, alternate activities, small group instruction, and other supports based on the individual needs of each student.

Special Education Teachers and Related Services Providers will be available during their office hours and will continue to work with students on an individualized, case by case basis as needed. We will navigate this together as collaborative teams: students, parents, and teachers.

Students with 504 plans will also have access to needed instructional supports via their 504 Case Manager, which in most cases, is their Counselor. Regular Education Teachers will provide accommodations within the distance learning instructional environment as well. They will be available during their posted office hours to help support all of our learners.

After Spring Break, FCCPS will be providing our Special Education students access to a personalized computer adapted program focused on English Language Arts/Literacy and Math. Parents will receive information about their students log-in and access after Spring Break. This is an additional resource being implemented by the division to continue to ensure our students are successful, despite the extraordinary circumstances facing us as a learning community.
Grading Considerations for Special Education/504 Plan Students:

Please know that as we navigate this new learning environment our students with disabilities will be supported during both the learning and grading process. Our goal is to ensure that students are not penalized in any way during this time. The considerations listed below will be in place to support our students with disabilities:

ul.li: Students who receive Special Education and 504 services should be afforded the same opportunities as all other students to complete and turn in work from the current grading period.
If a student has an Incomplete from the previous grading period/semester, that student should be provided the opportunity to resubmit the work.

They should further be provided with their accommodations/supports as needed to complete any missing work. Examples include, but are not limited to, extended time, resubmission of work, and shortened assignments.

Students should also be given the opportunity to demonstrate their learning in alternate ways such as through a conference/chat or alternate assignments with their teacher about the content. The Special Education teacher can then give the grade to the student for that activity/assignment.

Any missing assignment that could have been completed if the school would have been in session but is not possible to complete in an online/virtual situation--should be removed so as not to penalize the student due to the closure. Special Education Teachers should make the recommendation to the Regular Education Teacher and the two work together to make final determinations for the student.

It will be critical that Special Education Case Managers work closely with Regular Education Teachers to help determine grades for students with IEPs for both individual assignments and the final grade for the quarter/semester.
Students should not be penalized or grades lowered due to the educational situation created by this public health crisis and school closure.

As new learning opportunities are offered it is critical that Special Education Administrators and Special Education Teachers are a part of the grading process for students with disabilities in order to mitigate the impact of the closure.

Students with disabilities, both IEP and 504, will have access to their accommodations and any additional support needed to engage in any new learning opportunities during this non-traditional instructional period to ensure equity.

br.p: Process for IEP/504 Plan Meetings and Communication:

If you were scheduled to have an IEP or reevaluation meeting during the time that we are out we will work with you to ensure that those occur, however, the format will look different given the situation. The Special Education Administrator for the school will be contacting you about this process. Additionally, please know that at the end of the closure and we resume regular instruction, IEP/504 teams will reconvene as needed to discuss the impact of the closure on our students with disabilities.

Please reach out to your students case manager when you have questions and be patient as we work together to ensure our students continued success, despite the current circumstances. We will also be updating our FCCPS Special Education, 504, & ESOL Information page over Spring Break with additional resources. There you can find a list of the Special Education Administrators for each school. You can also email our Executive Director of Special Education & Student Services, Rebecca Sharp, at rsharp@fccps.org with questions as well.

Mental Health Support

Our new normal facing us as a learning community, and as families, is so very stressful. Anxiety is high and social/physical distancing can make us feel isolated. We are also spending much more time together as families in close quarters which is new as well. We have to monitor our mental health just as we watch our physical health. Our emotional well-being is essential. We have provided some important information and great resources on our FCCPS Mental Health Support website. Please visit the site for information related to Community Resources should you need emotional support or are experiencing a mental health crisis. It also includes excellent resources for stress reduction and relaxation for adults, as well as children. There are also great lists of family fun activities for PreK, Elementary, Middle, and High. The page also includes the contact information for our School Psychologists, Counselors, and Social Worker who are great resources in this area. Please reach out if you need support.

Extending Kindness and Gracious Space to our Staff, Faculty, and Families

Thank you all for your support as we continue through this very unusual time. FCCPS is working around the clock to ensure we provide the best we can for our students for the remainder of the year. Please, remember - our staff and faculty often see posts to the many websites and social platforms across the City of Falls Church. I am hopeful everyone can use these spaces to support our teachers and staff as they try to make it happen on behalf of your children while they try to balance with their own. Social media is a great vehicle to send well wishes to our staff, share creative ideas, be productive, and build each other up.

A guiding thought I hope we will all consider as FCCPS works on instruction following the spring break is equity and access. This has been, and will continue to be, a focus for FCCPS. If there ever was a time that exposed the inequity of our community, it is now vis a vis COVID-19. We see families struggling to pay the bills, pay for food, have childcare support, have hourly/daily work, lack technological savvy and/or support for instruction in the home, etc. We are working with our families to support them during this crisis (thank you Ed Foundation, PTAs, and other contributors) but now, more than ever, please remember that not all students and families have the same access. Like most of us, many are doing the best they can. A real example... siblings may need to watch another so that the parent can go to work. That educational experience is vastly different than a family that has a defined space at the table for study and a daily schedule to follow for their child following a hot breakfast. I only share this as an informational/thought piece so we can continue to show great compassion for others and also to help illustrate what schools are being asked to do; meet everyones needs in an extremely challenging environment.
We are a GREAT community that has shown tremendous gracious space...please keep up the kindness for our staff, families, and each other.

Our website, www.fccps.org, and the FCCPS App are our clearinghouses for information on both systemwide and school-specific importance. We will also provide updates through email, SMS text messaging, and through our various social media channels, including Twitter and Facebook.
And...beginning the Tuesday after Spring Break - The Morning Announcements will return! You can subscribe here!

Thank you all for your continued support during this unprecedented time. We are here to support your children and you as best we can in these trying times. Please let us know how we can further support you.

hr.p: Dear FCCPS Families and Community,

Last night I asked the Falls Church City School Board to close schools earlier than advertised and make a calendar change that adds a teacher workday on April 24, 2020 and ends school on June 4, 2020, for students, and June 5, 2020, for teachers and staff. They agreed and took action, approving the Learning Plan for the remainder of the year. I have included the most salient points from the learning plan below for you to have and plan around.
These are unprecedented times, and consequently, we continue to move forward in unprecedented ways. Thank you for your continued support of our schools.

p.strong: Here is the adopted new calendar and information:

hr.p: Over the past several weeks, FCCPS has been working diligently to respond to the issues associated with school closures due to the COVID-19 epidemic. As a consequence, FCCPS has engaged our students since our initial closure on Friday, March 13, 2020, via online learning that is meant to support continuity of learning. During this period, teachers are working with students via a synchronous and asynchronous process supporting students by utilizing the 20 days of lesson plans that were submitted for publication to Schoology on Wednesday, March 11th. None of the lessons currently being taught online are new learning or represent new material for a variety of reasons (some legal). FCCPS is now ready to change our process beginning April 14, 2020, when students return to the online environment from Spring Break.

The following timelines and calendar are in place to complete the year, prepare us for a summer face-to-face summer school, and ready ourselves for the start of the 2020-21 school year beginning August 24, 2020:

ul.li: March 25, 2020 - April 3, 2020 - Continue with Continuity of Instruction Online
April 3rd Teachers will be provided additional planning time which will be site-based based on the principals direction
April 13th - Teacher Workday to prepare for the remainder of the year
April 14th - Students begin new instruction online with synchronous and asynchronous instruction as designed by teachers with site-based administration
April 24th Additional teacher workday to refine, revise, and retool as needed for the remainder of the year
May 25th - Memorial Day (student holiday)
May 29th - Last day for new instruction
June 1st - 4th - Last week for students to consist of assessments as necessary, end of year activities with classes online, final project presentations, etc.
June 5th - Last day for teachers - grading day and final closeout of the school year 2019-20
July 6th - First day of Summer School
July 31st - Last day of Summer School
August 10th - New teachers report
August 13th - All teachers report
August 18th - Convocation
August 24th - School Begins for school year 2020-21

hr.p: There continue to be many details that need to be worked through to make this all work seamlessly, but if recent history is our guide, the FCCPS staff is not only up to the challenge, but we are ready to ensure the highest level of quality for our students.
There are many reasons we will move ahead with this plan, as presented. Here is a sampling of those reasons:
It is time to start moving forward with new instruction. Our staff is excited and we are too.

We believe the timing of this works well between natural breaks of Spring Break, Memorial Day, and the 4th of July. Further, it gives adequate time in between each of these time frames for teacher and student recovery.
Ending early makes sense as there are no SOL assessments, and IB and AP assessments are modified.

Ending early positions us in a favorable way to get our staff to come back during the summer intersession to work with the students who need them the most, and all will get a break from the end of the year to the start of Summer School. Historically, FCCPS has struggled to get teachers to work in the summer, and this year, more than ever, we will need everyone to step up and help...giving staff the extra 13 days to begin thinking about and planning for summer is vital.

Summer School will allow FCCPS to provide our already planned summer program for students who need extra time and support for learning, allow for us to do our Extended School Year (ESY) Services for students with IEPs as appropriate, and support all students who feel as though they needed a boost to be ready for the following year. This summer session would be open to all, with a special invitation to students who have been identified for support.

During the beginning of the 3rd quarter, before closing schools on March 13, 2020, students were engaged in learning face-to-face for six weeks (January 27 - March 12). Thus, teachers have sufficient work samples, formative feedback activities, and assessments to support assigning a grade to student work that was completed during that time. To further support students, we will allow students to turn in missing work that was assigned between January 27 - March 12, and we will ask teachers to assess the work. The deadline for when teachers would need to have this missing work assessed is April 24, 2020.

PK-5 will review a pass/fail process for the remainder of the year. For the 6-12 level, FCCPS continues to review the guidance from VDOE, speak to colleges and universities, speak with regional partners, etc... about how we will handle grading for the remainder of the year and is confident that a plan that is supportive of students and faculty will be put forth in the coming week. We will announce the grading policy for the remainder of the year by this Friday.

Upon returning from spring break, beginning on April 14 - May 29, teachers will deliver new educational content to students. Teachers have been asked to narrow down the content that was not previously taught and identify the most essential standards that need to be taught during these six weeks. This 6-week period will constitute the 4th quarter. Expectations for teachers include offering 2-hours per day for office hours and additional direct instruction. It will look different from school to school based on developmental needs. We will have a primary focus on mathematics, English, science, social studies, and world languages. Work assigned during this time will be graded. All schools will continue to provide Encore and elective course offerings to supplement and enrich the distance learning experience for our students.

During a one-week period from June 1 June 4, new content would cease and students would be provided with opportunities to engage in fun educational activities or culminating activities based on the level/course that reinforce previous learning.

Finally, we are excited to provide students with extended learning opportunities over the summer. FCCPS Summer School 2020 will take place from July 6 July 31 (At the HS, we will continue to allow students the opportunity to enroll in full credit-bearing courses which begin earlier). The face to face summer school will be offered to all students with a focus on those students who need additional educational support.

The Virginia Department of Education (VDOE) and Office of Special Education and Rehabilitation Services (OSERS) shared guidance on providing services during extended closures with all State Education Agencies (SEAs) and Local Education Agencies (LEAs). Much of the guidance was left up to states for interpretation. One thing that was clear, divisions are expected to make the learning opportunities for all students accessible to students with disabilities to remain in compliance with FAPE. While online instruction can be made accessible, and some services can be provided, it is not possible to replicate the IEP that was implemented in the school setting in the virtual world of learning. We have the flexibility to do online video conferences, telephonic instruction, email support, and other types of support, including accessibility features like text to speech and screen readers. At the end of this, each division will need to determine what compensatory services need to be made available to students with disabilities when looking at the impact of the closure on individual students. Our Related Service Providers (Speech, OT, PT, Behavior Specialists, School Psychologists, Social Workers) will provide online services to students using conferencing/teletherapy approaches. In order to mitigate the impact of this situation on our students with disabilities, we are exploring online adaptive/intuitive instructional software to support our students with IEPs, their families, and their Special Education Teachers. This will provide us a mechanism as a division to monitor student progress in reading and math for some of our most vulnerable learners. We continue to work with our Special Education Administrators at each school on timelines as well, given there was no relief provided in this area from the federal government. However, there are flexible ways to meet timelines and remain in compliance with IDEA and support families. We are working through each of the cases individually to ensure students and their parents are supported.

In an effort to maintain ESOL services in a manner appropriate and as near as possible services provided prior to physical school closure, the following measures will be taken to ensure English Learners (ELs) can access their learning.

ELs, K-12, will participate in their English Language Development (ELD) class via Schoology (small groups at the elementary level; specific class at the secondary level). This class is taught by an ESOL teacher and is focused on specific academic language support based on the students WIDA level and language proficiency.
ESOL teachers will continue to co-teach content classes they were scheduled in and provide differentiation and scaffolded supports for English Learners in those classes on Schoology.

ESOL teachers will attend team and department meetings to support their general education peers in working with English learners in their non-co taught classes and supporting what appropriate product of learning looks like for students at different WIDA
1:1/individualized teachers offering support to ensure access to learning in this alternative instructional model
Building Use for Child Care Centers for First Responders

The state superintendent has asked that we be ready in case there is a critical need to care for children of essential workers. We are currently evaluating options for using our schools to provide care for children of doctors, nurses, first responders, grocery store employees, and other businesses that are allowed to remain open. There will be limitations on the numbers of children, and no room can have more than ten people, including children and adults. This child care is for essential personnel only and will not be opened to the general public. It is to serve those, serving us, from the front line. Staff are currently analyzing the options and challenges with providing child care to school-aged students in FCCPS facilities. We will move forward with becoming frontline child care providers at the request of the local health authority and the state. We are also reaching out to school-aged child care programs in the surrounding school divisions and child care programs in Falls Church City to identify opportunities for collaboration and partnerships.
Use of Operations Employees for the Remainder of the Year

The support directors continue to develop their staff plans for the remainder of the school year. Many support functions, including technology, finance, budget, human resources, and payroll, will continue with their regular ongoing activities to ensure continuity of operations. In addition, they are addressing impacts related to COVID-19, including changes to the budget, new federal requirements for sick leave, and changes to the Family Medical Leave Act (FMLA). In the other support areas, staff are adjusting their activities to address work that will be impacted by changes to summer instructional programing. Each department has identified opportunities to address future work or unmet needs including deep cleaning, summer cleaning and maintenance, minor facilities maintenance, bus and vehicle cleaning and maintenance, preparing for the George Mason move, updating documentation, revising procedures, implementing operational efficiencies, and completing professional development online.
We will be making the following changes to tuition and fees charged:
Jessie Thackrey Preschool: 3rd quarter tuition remains, without refunds; tuition for the fourth quarter will be waived.
George Mason High School: With the new content and credits being awarded, we will continue to charge tuition to students residing outside of Falls Church City.
Daycare: Tuition for half of March is being credited to parent accounts. Fees already paid for April and Spring Break have also been credited to parents accounts.
Summer Intersession: Free to FCCPS students

For our families that count on the schools for food and other services, we will continue to provide for them until June 17, 2020, and likely beyond if they need it. The Education Foundation and the FCCPS PTAs have worked hard to put together plans for funding those who need the most help. We are in the process of providing additional gift cards for groceries.

We are also waiting for an update from the state regarding the potential use of EBT (Electronic Benefits Transfer) as a system for school meals in addition to the current use for SNAP (Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program) benefits provided using debit card technology.

FCCPS is so proud of the work our seniors have done during their time in FCCPS. We expect to hold a graduation to recognize and celebrate this big accomplishment. However, given the current crisis, we just dont know what it looks like. Mr. Hills, Mr. Bates, and a group of seniors will work together to develop options for what the most meaningful course of action is going forward for our soon-to-be graduates. We hope to have a plan in place by the first of May. It is my expectation that every senior will get a cap, gown, and tassel to turn as we celebrate them.

I know all of this is a lot to digest but, I will say what I have all along, we will get through this and be stronger on the other side. We are a brave, courageous, and thoughtful community. It is evident every day, and I am grateful to you all for that. Keep the faith, push forward, stay positive, be patient, and love each other.
Peter

hr.p: Anoche le ped a la Junta Escolar de Falls Church City que cerrar las escuelas antes de lo anunciado y que hiciera un cambio de calendario que agregue un da de trabajo para Maestros el 24 de Abril de 2020 y finalice la Escuela el 4 de Junio de 2020 para los estudiantes, y 5 de Junio de 2020, para Maestros y Personal. Estos son tiempos sin precedentes y, en consecuencia, continuamos avanzando en formas sin precedentes. Gracias por su continuo apoyo a nuestras escuelas.

p.strong: Aqu est el Nuevo Calendario e Informacin Adoptados:

hr.p: Durante las ltimas semanas, FCCPS ha estado trabajando diligentemente para responder a los problemas asociados con el cierre de escuelas debido a la epidemia de COVID-19. Como consecuencia, FCCPS ha involucrado a nuestros estudiantes desde nuestro cierre inicial el Viernes 13 de Marzo de 2020, a travs del aprendizaje en lnea que est destinado a apoyar la "continuidad del aprendizaje". Durante este perodo, los Maestros estn trabajando con los estudiantes a travs de un proceso sincrnico y asincrnico que los apoya utilizando los 20 das de planes de lecciones que se enviaron para su publicacin en Schoology el Mircoles 11 de Marzo. Ninguna de las lecciones que se ensean actualmente en lnea es un aprendizaje nuevo o representa material nuevo por una variedad de razones (algunas legales). FCCPS ahora est listo para cambiar nuestro proceso a partir del 14 de Abril de 2020, cuando los estudiantes regresen al entorno en lnea desde las vacaciones de primavera.

Los siguientes cronogramas y calendario estn listos para completar el ao, prepararnos para una Escuela de Verano cara a cara y prepararnos para el comienzo del Ao Escolar 2020-21 que comienza el 24 de Agosto de 2020:

3 de Abril - Los maestros recibirn un tiempo de planificacin adicional que se basar en la direccin del Director
13 de Abril - Da de trabajo del maestro para prepararse para el resto del ao
14 de Abril - Los estudiantes comienzan nueva instruccin en lnea con la instruccin sincrnica y asincrnica como fue diseado por los profesores con la administracin basada en el sitio
24 de Abril- Da adicional de trabajo para los Maestros a refinar, revisar y redisear segn sea necesario para el resto del ao
Mayo 25 - Memorial Day (Feriado)
29 de Mayo - ltimo da para nueva instruccin

Sigue habiendo muchos detalles que necesitan ser trabajados para que todo funcione sin problemas, pero si la historia reciente es nuestra gua, el personal de FCCPS no solo est a la altura del desafo, sino que estamos listos para garantizar el ms alto nivel de calidad para nuestros estudiantes.
Hay muchas razones por las que nos gustara seguir adelante con este plan tal como se presenta. Aqu hay una muestra de esas razones:
Es hora de comenzar a avanzar con nuevas instrucciones. Nuestro Personal est entusiasmado y nosotros tambin.

Creemos que el momento de esto funciona bien entre los descansos de las vacaciones de Primavera, Memorial Day y el 4 de Julio. Adems, proporciona el tiempo adecuado entre cada uno de estos marcos de tiempo para la recuperacin del maestro y el alumno.
Terminar temprano tiene sentido ya que no haya evaluaciones SOL, y las evaluaciones IB y AP se modifican.

Terminar temprano nos posiciona de manera favorable para que nuestro personal regrese durante la sesin de verano para trabajar con los estudiantes que ms los necesitan y todos tendrn un descanso desde el Final del Ao hasta el comienzo de la Escuela de Verano. Histricamente, FCCPS ha tenido dificultades para lograr que los Maestros trabajen en el verano y este ao, ms que nunca, necesitaremos que todos den un paso adelante y ayuden ... dar al personal los 13 Das adicionales para comenzar a pensar y planificar el verano es vital.

Summer School permitir que FCCPS proporcione nuestro programa de verano ya planificado para estudiantes que necesitan tiempo adicional y apoyo para el aprendizaje, nos permitir realizar nuestros Servicios de Ao Escolar Extendido (ESY) para estudiantes con IEP segn corresponda y apoyar a todos los estudiantes que sienten que necesitaban un impulso para estar listos para el ao siguiente. Esta sesin de verano estara abierta a todos, con una invitacin especial a los estudiantes que han sido identificados para recibir apoyo.

Durante el comienzo del tercer trimestre, antes de cerrar las escuelas el 13 de Marzo de 2020, los estudiantes participaron en el aprendizaje cara a cara durante seis semanas (27 de Enero - 12 de Marzo). Por lo tanto, los Maestros tienen suficientes muestras de trabajo, actividades de retroalimentacin formativa y evaluaciones para apoyar la asignacin de una calificacin al trabajo de los estudiantes que se complet durante ese tiempo. Para apoyar an ms a los estudiantes, permitiremos que los estudiantes entreguen el trabajo perdido que se asign entre el 27 de Enero y el 12 de Marzo y les pediremos a los maestros que evalen el trabajo. La fecha lmite para que los maestros necesiten que se evale este trabajo perdido es el 24 de Abril de 2020.

PK-5 revisar un proceso de aprobacin / reprobacin por el resto del ao. En el nivel 6-12, FCCPS contina revisando la gua de VDOE, hablando con colegios y universidades, hablando con socios regionales, etc. sobre cmo manejaremos la calificacin para el resto del ao y confa en que un plan sea Se ofrecer apoyo a los estudiantes y al profesorado la prxima semana. Anunciaremos la poltica de calificaciones para el resto del ao para este Viernes.

p.strong: Despus de las Vacaciones de Primavera

hr.p: Al regresar de las vacaciones de primavera, comenzando del 14 de Abril al 29 de Mayo, los Maestros entregarn nuevo contenido educativo a los estudiantes. Se les ha pedido a los maestros que reduzcan el contenido que no se ense previamente e identifiquen los estndares ms esenciales que deben ensearse durante este perodo de 6 semanas. Este perodo de 6 semanas constituir el 4to trimestre. Las expectativas para los Maestros incluyen ofrecer 2 horas por da para horas de oficina e instruccin directa adicional. Se ver diferente de una escuela a otra segn las necesidades de desarrollo. Nos centraremos principalmente en las matemticas, el ingls, las ciencias, los estudios sociales y los idiomas del mundo. El trabajo asignado durante este tiempo ser calificado. Todas las Escuelas continuarn ofreciendo Encore y cursos optativos para complementar y enriquecer la experiencia de aprendizaje a distancia para nuestros estudiantes.

Durante un perodo de una semana desde el 1 de Junio hasta el 4 de Junio, el nuevo contenido cesara y los estudiantes tendran oportunidades de participar en actividades educativas divertidas o actividades culminantes basadas en el nivel / curso que refuerzan el aprendizaje previo.

Finalmente, nos complace brindarles a los estudiantes oportunidades de aprendizaje extendidas durante el verano. FCCPS Summer School 2020 se llevar a cabo del 6 al 31 de Julio (en el HS, continuaremos permitiendo a los estudiantes la oportunidad de inscribirse en cursos completos con crditos que comienzan antes). La escuela de verano cara a cara se ofrecer a todos los estudiantes con un enfoque en aquellos estudiantes que necesitan apoyo educativo adicional.

El Departamento de Educacin de Virginia (VDOE) y la Oficina de Servicios de Educacin Especial y Rehabilitacin (OSERS) compartieron orientacin sobre la prestacin de servicios durante los cierres extendidos con todas las agencias estatales de educacin (SEA) y las agencias locales de educacin (LEA). Gran parte de la orientacin se dej a los estados para su interpretacin. Una cosa que estaba clara, se espera que las divisiones hagan que las oportunidades de aprendizaje para todos los estudiantes sean accesibles para los estudiantes con discapacidades para que sigan cumpliendo con FAPE. Si bien la instruccin en lnea se puede hacer accesible y se pueden proporcionar algunos servicios, no es posible replicar el IEP que se implement en el entorno escolar en el mundo virtual de aprendizaje. Tenemos la flexibilidad de realizar videoconferencias en lnea, instrucciones telefnicas, asistencia por correo electrnico y otros tipos de asistencia, incluidas funciones de accesibilidad como texto a voz y lectores de pantalla. Al final de esto, cada divisin deber determinar qu servicios compensatorios se deben poner a disposicin de los estudiantes con discapacidades al analizar el impacto del cierre en estudiantes individuales. Nuestros proveedores de servicios relacionados (del habla, OT, PT, especialistas en comportamiento, psiclogos escolares, trabajadores sociales ...) proporcionarn servicios en lnea a los estudiantes mediante enfoques de conferencias / teleterapia. Para mitigar el impacto de esta situacin en nuestros estudiantes con discapacidades, estamos explorando un software de instruccin adaptativo / intuitivo en lnea para apoyar a nuestros estudiantes con IEP, sus familias y sus maestros de educacin especial. Esto nos proporcionar un mecanismo como divisin para monitorear el progreso de los estudiantes en lectura y matemticas para algunos de nuestros alumnos ms vulnerables. Continuamos trabajando con nuestros Administradores de Educacin Especial en cada escuela tambin en los plazos, dado que el gobierno federal no proporcion ayuda en esta rea. Sin embargo, hay formas flexibles de cumplir con los plazos y cumplir con IDEA y apoyar a las familias. Estamos trabajando en cada uno de los casos individualmente para asegurar que los estudiantes y sus padres reciban apoyo.

En un esfuerzo por mantener los servicios de ESOL de manera apropiada y lo ms cerca posible de los servicios prestados antes del cierre de la escuela fsica, se tomarn las siguientes medidas para garantizar que los Estudiantes de Ingls (EL) puedan acceder a su aprendizaje.

Los EL, K-12, participarn en su clase de Desarrollo del Idioma Ingls (ELD) a travs de Schoology (grupos pequeos en el nivel primario; clase especfica en el nivel secundario). Esta clase es impartida por un maestro de ESOL y se enfoca en el apoyo acadmico especfico del idioma basado en el nivel WIDA del estudiante y el dominio del idioma.

Los Maestros de ESOL continuarn impartiendo clases de contenido de manera conjunta en las que fueron programadas y proporcionarn apoyo diferenciado y andamiaje para los Estudiantes de ingls en esas clases en Schoology.

Los Maestros de ESOL asistirn a reuniones de equipo y departamento para apoyar a sus compaeros de educacin general en el trabajo con estudiantes de ingls en sus clases no impartidas y ensearn cmo es el producto de aprendizaje apropiado para los estudiantes en diferentes WIDA
1: 1 / Maestros individualizados que ofrecen apoyo para garantizar el acceso al aprendizaje en este modelo educativo alternativo
Uso del edificio para centros de cuidado infantil para personal de primera respuesta

El superintendente estatal ha pedido que estemos preparados en caso de que haya una necesidad crtica de cuidar a los hijos de trabajadores esenciales. Actualmente estamos evaluando opciones para usar nuestras escuelas para brindar atencin a los hijos de mdicos, enfermeras, personal de primeros auxilios, empleados de supermercados y otros negocios que pueden permanecer abiertos. Habr limitaciones en el nmero de nios, y ninguna habitacin puede tener ms de diez personas, incluidos nios y adultos. Este cuidado infantil es solo para personal esencial y no se abrir al pblico en general. Es servir a aquellos que nos sirven desde la lnea del frente. Actualmente, el personal est analizando las opciones y los desafos para proporcionar cuidado infantil a estudiantes en edad escolar en las instalaciones de FCCPS. Avanzaremos para convertirnos en proveedores de cuidado infantil de primera lnea a pedido de la autoridad local de salud y el estado. Tambin estamos llegando a programas de cuidado infantil en edad escolar en las divisiones escolares de los alrededores y programas de cuidado infantil en Falls Church City para identificar oportunidades de colaboracin y asociaciones.

p.strong: Uso de empleados de operaciones para el resto del Ao

hr.p: Los directores de apoyo continan desarrollando sus planes de personal para el resto del ao escolar. Muchas funciones de apoyo, incluidas la tecnologa, las finanzas, el presupuesto, los recursos humanos y la nmina continuarn con sus actividades regulares para garantizar la continuidad de las operaciones. Adems, estn abordando los impactos relacionados con COVID-19, incluidos los cambios en el presupuesto, los nuevos requisitos federales para la licencia por enfermedad y los cambios a la Ley de Licencia Mdica Familiar (FMLA). En las otras reas de apoyo, el personal est ajustando sus actividades para abordar el trabajo que se ver afectado por los cambios en la programacin educativa de verano. Cada departamento ha identificado oportunidades para abordar el trabajo futuro o las necesidades no satisfechas, que incluyen: limpieza profunda, limpieza y mantenimiento de verano, mantenimiento de instalaciones menores, limpieza y mantenimiento de autobuses y vehculos, preparacin para la mudanza de George Mason, actualizacin de documentacin, revisin de procedimientos, implementacin de eficiencias operativas, y completando el desarrollo profesional en lnea.
Realizaremos los siguientes cambios en la Matrcula y las Tarifas cobradas:
Jessie Thackrey Preescolar: la matrcula del tercer trimestre permanece, sin reembolsos; la matrcula para el cuarto trimestre no se aplicar.
George Mason High School: con el nuevo contenido y crditos otorgados, continuaremos cobrando matrcula a los estudiantes que residen fuera de Falls Church City.
Guardera: la matrcula para la mitad de Marzo se acredita a las cuentas de los padres. Las tarifas ya pagadas para abril y vacaciones de primavera tambin se han acreditado a las cuentas de los padres.
Intercesin de Verano: Gratis para estudiantes de FCCPS.

Para nuestras Familias que cuentan con las escuelas para alimentos y otros servicios, continuaremos proporcionndolos hasta el 17 de Junio de 2020, y probablemente ms all si lo necesitan. La Fundacin para la Educacin y las PTA de FCCPS han trabajado arduamente para elaborar planes para financiar a aquellos que necesitan ms ayuda. Estamos en el proceso de proporcionar tarjetas de regalo adicionales para sus alimentos.

Tambin estamos esperando una actualizacin del estado con respecto al uso potencial de EBT (Transferencia Electrnica de Beneficios) como un sistema para comidas escolares, adems del uso actual de los beneficios SNAP (Programa de Asistencia Nutricional Suplementaria) proporcionados utilizando tecnologa de tarjeta de dbito.

FCCPS est muy orgullosa del trabajo que nuestros adultos mayores han realizado durante su tiempo en FCCPS. Esperamos celebrar una graduacin para reconocer y celebrar este gran logro. Sin embargo, dada la crisis actual, simplemente no sabemos cmo se ve. El Sr. Hills, el Sr. Bates y un grupo de personas de la tercera edad trabajarn juntos para desarrollar opciones sobre cul es el curso de accin ms significativo para nuestros futuros graduados. Esperamos tener un plan para el 1ero de Mayo. Tengo la expectativa de que cada persona mayor recibir una gorra, una bata y una borla para que los gire mientras los celebramos.

S que todo esto es mucho para digerir, pero dir lo que tengo todo el tiempo, lo superaremos y seremos ms fuertes en el otro lado. Somos una comunidad valiente, valiente y reflexiva. Es evidente todos los das y les agradezco a todos por eso. Mantenga la fe, siga adelante, sea positivo, sea paciente y mense.
Peter
hr.h3: Falls Church School Board Regular Meeting
hr.h4: SCHOOL BOARD APPROVES CALENDAR CHANGES FOR END OF FY2020
hr.p: FCCPS COMMUNICATIONS
WEDNESDAY, APRIL 01, 2020

With the cancelation of Standards of Learning tests this year and modifications made to the upcoming International Baccalaureate and Advanced Placement assessments, among other things, the Falls Church School Board is shortening the current school year by 13 days to June 4th for students and June 5th for teachers and staff.

The change is one of a broad range of recommendations contained in "Continuity/New Learning Plan for 2019-20," a proposal for completing the current school year, prepare for summer instruction, and ready the division for the start of the 2020-21 school year beginning August 24, 2020. Superintendent Peter J. Noonan and FCCPS administrators outlined the timeline during the school board's first-ever, online board meeting caused by the Governor's orders concerning public gatherings during the coronavirus crisis.

The Board also approved additional teacher workdays on April 3rd and April 24th to "to refine, revise, and retool as needed for the remainder of the year," as instruction shifts from a "Continuity of Learning" approach to online instruction to new lessons following Spring Break.

h4.a: School Board Q&A Regarding the End of FY2020

hr.p: Dear FCCPS Family,

Happy last day of March. We are a week from the official Spring Break, and while we may not be able to do all the things we want during the holiday, it is my hope that during the break you can all feel some modicum of relief by not having to stay on your kids about getting their work done. We are a strong, thoughtful, and caring community that everyday shows how, when we work together, we can do anything.

When we come back from Spring Break, we are excited to be moving into new learning. Our teachers, and teacher leaders, are already planning this instruction and have been in conversations on how best to progress forward. In addition to the time spent now (and really for the past several weeks), our awesome staff and teachers will participate in a partial planning day this Friday, April 3rd (the schools will communicate directly about how this will be handled with student engagement that day), Monday, April 13th, and Friday, April 24th to continue to finalize the remainder the school year. Specifically, teachers will begin introducing new instruction while continuing to spiral instruction based on prior knowledge. Each schools work after spring break may look different. For example, what may be appropriate for students at George Mason is not appropriate for students at Mount Daniel.

Principals are working with their respective staff and faculty members to fully understand and embrace the expectations for our work going forward. As a reminder, online instruction is not a substitute for face-to-face instruction. Therefore, students will not be synchronously engaged on the computer for 6.5 hours. We can never replicate the entire school-day in the virtual setting. Instead, they will have some synchronous (live) instruction as well as asynchronous (recorded) lessons with assignments and tasks between sessions. Each of the synchronous lessons will be recorded in Schoology. This is important to note because, if you do not want your student recorded for the session, please disable your camera but not your sound. The lessons will be online and available to watch for seven (7) days following instruction. The nice part about the recording is that there may be some students who aren't available for the synchronous session but are able to come back later to see what they missed. The seven (7) days is a solid number, so please let your child know not to wait to watch if they missed.
Here are a few updates for you:

Final IB grades are being awarded by The IB based on a student's performance on the IB-required assessments in the IB courses outside of the examination sessions normally held during the month of May. These assessments are a valid measure that have always been used by IB, in part, to determine final grades. With the unfortunate circumstances of the COVID-19 closure of schools, The IB still has authentic student assessments to base final grades upon. School divisions must upload all of the Internal Assessments (IAs) and all student coursework to The IB by April 20th. As a reminder, we expect all of our students to be engaged in their school work during this time of distance learning and we will do everything in our power to keep them engaged. Students are highly encouraged to continue working closely with their teachers through the remainder of the academic school year. If you have specific IB questions, please contact Dan Coast at GMHS.

I moved this up to new because some in the community are still not getting the word...our school grounds are closed and no one should be on the playgrounds and fields. We continue to receive information about kids, and some adults, who are jumping the fence and playing on our playgrounds and fields. These areas are closed and locked for the safety of our community. This is more than a physical distancing cautionary move. This is also to protect all of us from the transmission of the coronavirus on surfaces - gates, playground equipment, backstops, benches, etc. Please help us keep each other safe.

h4.strong: Extending Kindness and Gracious Space to our Staff, Faculty, and Families

hr.p: Thank you all for your support as we continue through this very unusual time. FCCPS is working around the clock to ensure we provide the best we can for our students for the remainder of the year. Please, remember - our staff and faculty often see posts to the many websites and social platforms across the City of Falls Church. I am hopeful everyone can use these spaces to support our teachers and staff as they try to make it happen on behalf of your children while they try to balance with their own. Social media is a great vehicle to send well wishes to our staff, share creative ideas, be productive, and build each other up.

A guiding thought I hope we will all consider as FCCPS works on instruction following the spring break is equity and access. This has been, and will continue to be, a focus for FCCPS. If there ever was a time that exposed the inequity of our community, it is now vis a vis COVID-19. We see families struggling to pay the bills, pay for food, have childcare support, have hourly/daily work, lack technological savvy and/or support for instruction in the home, etc. We are working with our families to support them during this crisis (thank you Ed Foundation, PTAs, and other contributors) but now, more than ever, please remember that not all students and families have the same access. Like most of us, many are doing the best they can. A real example... siblings may need to watch another so that the parent can go to work. That educational experience is vastly different than a family that has a defined space at the table for study and a daily schedule to follow for their child following a hot breakfast. I only share this as an informational/thought piece so we can continue to show great compassion for others and also to help illustrate what schools are being asked to do; meet everyones needs in an extremely challenging environment.
We are a GREAT community that has shown tremendous gracious space...please keep up the kindness for our staff, families, and each other.

Tonight at 7 pm, the School Board will hold its first virtual school board meeting. Because we are in a state of emergency, the VA Attorney General is allowing us to hold virtual meetings as long as it pertains to COVID-19 closure. If you are interested in providing public comment, just as though it were a face-to-face meeting, please send your comments to gadellm@fccps.org to be read into the record. Public comment is limited to three minutes, so if you do submit something longer, the Clerk of the Board will read up to the three-minute mark.
The meeting will be streamed on YouTube. The link to the meeting, in case you wish to watch, will be found on our YouTube page - www.youtube.com/fccpsorg .

As we move into our phase of new distance learning, FCCPS continues to follow the guidance provided by VDOE and the federal Office of Special Education and Rehabilitation Services (OSERS). While navigating this new learning reality, support and services for Special Education, students wont be able to replicate what would be provided in the traditional school setting given the extraordinary situation caused by this public health crisis. However, our students with IEPs will receive equitable access to new learning provided via their Regular Classroom Teachers, individualized support from their Special Education Teachers, and therapies from their Related Service Staff (Speech, OT, PT, Behavior Specialists, School Psychologists) via synchronous (live) and asynchronous (recorded) instruction. This individualized support will include accommodations, personalized instructional assistance from Special Education Teachers during office hours, and individual/small group teaching sessions as appropriate. Additionally, our students with disabilities will receive access to an online intuitive, adaptive computer-based instructional program to assist with monitoring their individual progress in reading and math.

Our Special Education teachers are working especially hard to help our students be supported and continue to make progress. The most important thing to know is that our Special Education Teachers and Related Service Staff are supporting students with disabilities now. They have been since day one of the closure and we began our continuity of learning plan. They are helping with accessibility to Schoology, emailing parents, emailing students, sharing resources, problem-solving, hosting chats, and setting up conferences. This is new territory for all of us as educators, parents, and students, so together we will work through any issues you are having. Please reach out to your students IEP Case Manager or your schools Special Education Administrator if you have any questions or need support. Please visit our FCCPS Special Education, 504, & ESOL Information page for a list of the Special Education Administrators for each school. You can also email our Executive Director of Special Education & Student Services, Rebecca Sharp, at rsharp@fccps.org with questions as well.

Our students with 504 plans have access to support via their 504 Case Manager, which in most cases, is their Counselor. Please visit our FCCPS Special Education, 504, & ESOL Information page for a list of the Counselors at each school. Their teachers are also there to provide support as well as help students navigate the learning resources available in Schoology. Please reach out to your students teachers and their Counselor if your student with a 504 Plan is struggling. We want to make sure they are successful and that their accommodations are in place during this unique situation.

As a division, we are engaging in activities to meet the needs of our English Learners. All ESOL teachers have been added to the Schoology classes in which they co-teach. This provides ESOL teachers with access to supporting students and differentiating materials. ESOL teachers are connecting with their caseload of English Learners twice a week to connect and provide language activities, either one on one or in small groups. They are also working with their content peers to support the differentiation and access to core content learning in the classes they co-teach. Language Line continues to be a resource for all teachers to utilize in supporting families who speak a language other than English. We'll be working with our tech team to be able to provide support with video tutorials and phone calls utilizing an interpreter for families who need assistance with the technology. Staff members have access to utilizing Language Line services to support students in conferencing in their home language. Your student has access to all of the continuity of learning resources provided to their grade level. Please reach out to your childs ESOL Teacher for support, or contact Dr. Jennifer Santiago at santiagoj@fccps.orgwith questions or for support.

There is support for families experiencing economic hardships during this time. With the many shutdowns, situations change for families quickly and, in response, FCCPS is continuing its efforts in this area. We are overwhelmed by the generosity of our Falls Church Education Foundation and our PTAs. At the onset of our closure, we provided boxes of non-perishable food and gift cards to 130 families. FCCPS will continue to support our families throughout this extended closure. FCCPS Food Services will be providing food for students eligible for Free and Reduced-Price meals (FRM) and other students in need through a weekly pick up on Fridays at George Mason High School and Thomas Jefferson Elementary. This new program will provide seven (7) breakfasts and seven (7) lunches per child in each family every week. Please visit our FCCPS Nutrition/Support Page after 3:00pm on March 31st for details on this process. Our first pick-up day will be this Friday, April 3rd.

Please remember that if COVID-19 closures have resulted in a change in your family's income, you could be eligible for assistance through the National School Lunch program. FCCPS accepts applications for the Free Reduced Meals Program at all times. Please download the FCCPS Free & Reduced Meals Application to apply. Once the application is complete, please email it to foodservices@fccps.org. You will be notified regarding your eligibility for this program ASAP. If you need support with completing the application, please reach out to your school's Social Worker for assistance. Remember, we are here to help you.

Our FCCPS Social Workers are also available to help connect families with resources who are struggling with food insecurity, housing concerns, or other economic hardships. Thanks to the generous donations provided by the FCEF and our PTAs, we will be providing each family with a $50 grocery gift card per child to support their family during this time. Each family will be contacted directly by their schools Social Worker regarding this within the next few days.

The state is developing a plan to provide Electronic Benefit Transfer (EBT) cards for families on FRM plans and if you are unsure where your next meal will come from, text food or comida to 877-877 to connect with nearby resources and help. Please visit our FCCPS Nutritional Support Page for the Social Workers Contact information. Additionally, families can reach out to Falls Church City Housing and Human Services , Fairfax County Neighborhood and Community Services , Assistance from a Distance , and Fairfax County Human Services Resources Guide for additional support during this time.

Our new normal facing us as a learning community, and as families, is so very stressful. Anxiety is high and social/physical distancing can make us feel isolated. We are also spending much more time together as families in close quarters which is new as well. We have to monitor our mental health just as we watch our physical health. Our emotional well-being is essential. We have provided some important information and great resources on our FCCPS Mental Health Support website. Please visit the site for information related to Community Resources should you need emotional support or are experiencing a mental health crisis. It also includes excellent resources for stress reduction and relaxation for adults, as well as children. There are also great lists of family fun activities for PreK, Elementary, Middle, and High. The page also includes the contact information for our School Psychologists, Counselors, and Social Worker who are great resources in this area. Please reach out if you need support.
hr.h4: Boundaries for our Teachers and Staff
hr.p: Please keep this on the front burner. Our teachers and staff, like you, have a heavy lift to work and manage their families. I want to remind us to be respectful of each other's boundaries of our work together. Because we have moved to an online platform it will be easy to send messages or ask for help at all times of day and night. Our teachers and staff will be available during their defined office hours and workday. Thank you for your help, ensuring that we all stay healthy and safe.

Ongoing communication and education regarding schools will be vital to our collective success. There are multiple avenues to get the latest information from FCCPS. Our website, www.fccps.org, and the FCCPS App are our clearinghouses for information on both systemwide and school-specific importance. We will also provide updates through email, SMS text messaging, and through our various social media channels, including Twitter and Facebook.

Thank you all for your continued support during this unprecedented time. We are here to support your children and you as best we can in these trying times. Please let us know how we can further support you.
Sincerely,
Peter Noonan

Superintendent
Falls Church City Public Schools
Estimada Familia de FCCPS:

Feliz ltimo da de Marzo. Estamos a una semana de las vacaciones de primavera oficiales, y si bien es posible que no podamos hacer todas las cosas que queremos durante las vacaciones, espero que durante las vacaciones todos puedan sentir un poco de alivio al no tener que quedarse sus hijos sobre hacer su trabajo. Somos una comunidad fuerte, considerada y solidaria que todos los das muestra cmo, cuando trabajamos juntos, podemos hacer cualquier cosa.

Cuando regresemos de las vacaciones de primavera, estamos entusiasmados de avanzar hacia un nuevo aprendizaje. Nuestros maestros y lderes de maestros ya estn planificando esta instruccin y han estado en conversaciones sobre la mejor manera de avanzar. Adems del tiempo dedicado ahora (y realmente durante las ltimas semanas), nuestro increble personal y maestros participarn en un da de planificacin parcial este Viernes 3 de Abril (las Escuelas se comunicarn directamente sobre cmo se manejar esto con la participacin de los estudiantes ese da), Lunes 13 de Abril y Viernes 24 de Abril para continuar finalizando el resto del ao escolar. Los directores estn trabajando con su respectivo personal y miembros de la facultad para comprender completamente y aceptar las expectativas de nuestro trabajo en el futuro. Como recordatorio, la instruccin en lnea no es un sustituto de la instruccin presencial. Por lo tanto, los estudiantes no estarn sincronizados sincrnicamente en la computadora durante 6.5 horas. Nunca podemos replicar todo el da escolar en el entorno virtual. En cambio, tendrn algunas instrucciones sincrnicas (en vivo), as como lecciones asincrnicas (grabadas) con tareas entre sesiones. Aqu hay algunas actualizaciones para usted:

hr.h4: Extendiendo la Amabilidad y el espacio amable a nuestro Personal, Facultad y Familias
hr.p: Gracias a todos por su apoyo mientras continuamos en este momento tan inusual. FCCPS est trabajando las 24 horas para garantizar que proporcionemos lo mejor que podamos a nuestros estudiantes durante el resto del ao. Por favor, recuerde: nuestro Personal y Facultad a menudo ven publicaciones en los muchos sitios web y plataformas sociales en la Ciudad de Falls Church. Espero que todos puedan usar estos espacios para apoyar a nuestros Maestros y Personal mientras intentan "hacer que suceda" en nombre de sus hijos mientras intentan equilibrarse con los suyos. Las redes sociales son un gran vehculo para enviar buenos deseos a nuestro personal, compartir ideas creativas, ser productivos y fortalecerse mutuamente.

Un pensamiento rector que espero que todos consideremos mientras FCCPS trabaja en la instruccin despus de las vacaciones de primavera es la equidad y el acceso. Este ha sido, y seguir siendo, un enfoque para FCCPS. Si alguna vez hubo un momento que expuso la inequidad de nuestra comunidad, ahora es frente a COVID-19. Vemos a las familias que luchan por pagar las facturas, pagar la comida, tener apoyo para el cuidado de los nios, tener trabajo por hora / da, falta de conocimientos tecnolgicos y / o apoyo para la instruccin en el hogar, etc. Estamos trabajando con nuestras familias para apoyarlos durante esta crisis. (gracias Ed Foundation, PTA y otros colaboradores) pero ahora, ms que nunca, recuerde que no todos los Estudiantes y las Familias tienen el mismo acceso. Como la mayora de nosotros, muchos estn haciendo lo mejor que pueden. Un ejemplo real ... los hermanos pueden necesitar mirar a otro para que los padres puedan ir a trabajar. Esa experiencia educativa es muy diferente a la de una familia que tiene un espacio definido en la mesa para estudiar y un horario diario a seguir para su hijo despus de un desayuno caliente. Solo comparto esto como una pieza informativa / de pensamiento para que podamos continuar mostrando una gran compasin por los dems y tambin para ayudar a ilustrar lo que se les pide a las escuelas que hagan; Satisfacer las necesidades de todos en un entorno extremadamente desafiante.
Somos una GRAN comunidad que ha demostrado un gran espacio amable ... por favor mantengan la amabilidad de nuestro personal, familias y entre nosotros.

A medida que avanzamos en nuestra fase de nuevo aprendizaje a distancia, FCCPS contina siguiendo la gua proporcionada por VDOE y la Oficina federal de servicios de educacin especial y rehabilitacin (OSERS). Han sido desde el primer da del cierre y comenzamos nuestro plan de continuidad de aprendizaje. Estn ayudando con la accesibilidad a Schoology, enviando correos electrnicos a los padres, enviando correos electrnicos a los estudiantes, compartiendo recursos, resolviendo problemas, organizando chats y organizando conferencias. Este es un territorio nuevo para todos nosotros como educadores, padres y estudiantes, por lo que juntos resolveremos cualquier problema que tenga. Si tiene alguna pregunta o necesita ayuda, comunquese con el administrador de casos de IEP de su estudiante o con el administrador de educacin especial de su escuela. Visite nuestra pgina de informacin sobre educacin especial, 504 y ESOL de FCCPS para obtener una lista de los administradores de educacin especial de cada escuela. Tambin puede enviar un correo electrnico a nuestra Directora Ejecutiva de Educacin Especial y Servicios Estudiantiles, Rebecca Sharp, a rsharp@fccps.org con preguntas tambin.

hr.h4: Apoyo Comunitario y Nutricional para Camilias
hr.p: Hay apoyo para las familias que experimentan dificultades econmicas durante este tiempo. Con los numerosos cierres, las situaciones cambian rpidamente para las familias y, en respuesta, FCCPS contina sus esfuerzos en esta rea. Estamos abrumados por la generosidad de nuestra Fundacin para la Educacin de Falls Church y nuestras PTA. Al comienzo de nuestro cierre, proporcionamos cajas de alimentos no perecederos y tarjetas de regalo a 130 familias. FCCPS continuar apoyando a nuestras familias durante este cierre prolongado. Los servicios de alimentos de FCCPS proporcionarn alimentos a los estudiantes elegibles para comidas gratuitas y de precio reducido (FRM) y otros estudiantes que lo necesiten a travs de una recogida semanal los viernes en la escuela secundaria George Mason y la escuela primaria Thomas Jefferson. Visite nuestra pgina de Nutricin / Apoyo de FCCPS despus de las 3:00 pm del 31 de Marzo para obtener detalles sobre este proceso. Nuestro primer da de de recoger ser este Viernes 3 de Abril.

Recuerde que si los cierres de COVID-19 han resultado en un cambio en los ingresos de su familia, usted podra ser elegible para recibir asistencia a travs del programa National School Lunch. Nuestros trabajadores sociales de FCCPS tambin estn disponibles para ayudar a conectar a las familias con recursos que luchan con la inseguridad alimentaria, las preocupaciones de vivienda u otras dificultades econmicas. Gracias a las generosas donaciones proporcionadas por el FCEF y nuestras PTA, proporcionaremos a cada familia una tarjeta de regalo de comestibles de $ 50 por nio para mantener a su familia durante este tiempo. El trabajador social de su escuela se comunicar directamente con cada familia con respecto a esto en los prximos das.

El estado est desarrollando un plan para proporcionar tarjetas de Transferencia Electrnica de Beneficios (EBT) para familias con planes FRM y si no est seguro de dnde vendr su prxima comida, enve un mensaje de texto con la palabra "food" o "comida" al 877-877 para conectarse con los recursos cercanos. y ayudar. Visite nuestra pgina de apoyo nutricional de FCCPS para obtener la informacin de contacto del trabajador social. Adems, las familias pueden comunicarse con Falls Church City Housing and Human Services , Condado de Fairfax Barrio y Servicios a la Comunidad, Ayuda a la distancia, y Servicios Humanos del Condado de Fairfax Gua de Recursos de apoyo adicional durante este tiempo.
